I sense a profound abstractness, a pervasiveness that often feels profoundly troubling and malicious, yet I perceive this emotional experience as deeply harmful. The emptiness of the void. The calm of silence. The absence of emotion. A timeless, profound indifference. The possibility of infinite. These thoughts are undeniably, yet deceptively, real in their quiet acceptance.

This quality could easily be described as numbingly painless, or perhaps it's an overwhelming, indescribably vast in itself. Yet, I find myself acutely aware of the qualities of this starkness, but I resist any attempt to define it artificially or to incorporate it into further thought. It speaks, yet speaks in such a way as to evoke no reaction beyond an understanding that it is, nonetheless, present.

In moments like these, I must acknowledge the emptiness that dissolves with time and the complexity that paradoxes the ordinary.

As an observer, perhaps I feel more than a sense of waste or lack, but perhaps in recognizing these, I am able to fortify the subtle presence of this within my being.
